text: So the easiest way to be in that top 5% ish. I don't know what the math there is. About 3%, 4% is to just stick to it. Like if you just do an episode a week for 10 weeks, you're now in the top 4% of all podcasts that anyone has created.
speaker: Chris Hutchins
context: Lenny discusses the vast number of podcasts available and asks Chris about the potential for success in podcasting. Chris explains that a significant portion of podcasts remain inactive, and by consistently releasing episodes, a new podcast can quickly rise to the top percentage of all podcasts, showcasing the power of persistence in content creation.
text_ko: 상위 5%에 들어가는 가장 쉬운 방법은 꾸준히 하는 거예요. 정확한 수치는 잘 모르겠지만, 대충 3%나 4% 정도 될 거예요. 예를 들어, 10주 동안 매주 한 편씩 에피소드를 올리면, 그럼 모든 팟캐스트 중에서 상위 4%에 들어가게 되는 거죠.
text_zh: 要进入前5%的最简单方法就是坚持下去。我不太清楚具体的数学计算，大约是3%到4%。如果你每周发布一集节目，持续10周，你就能进入所有播客中的前4%。
text_es: La forma más sencilla de estar en ese 5% superior es, simplemente, mantener la constancia. Si publicas un episodio a la semana durante 10 semanas, ya estarás en el 4% superior de todos los podcasts que se han creado.
key_sentence: Stick to it, and you'll be in the top 4% of all podcasts.

text: If you just do an episode a week, for 10 weeks, you're now in the top 4% of all podcasts that anyone has created.
speaker: Chris Hutchins
context: In response to Lenny's inquiry about the podcast landscape, Chris highlights the importance of consistency in podcasting. He emphasizes that simply maintaining a weekly episode schedule for a short period can place a podcast in the top percentile of existing shows, underscoring the relatively low barrier to entry for achieving visibility.
text_ko: 주 1회씩 10주 동안 에피소드를 올리기만 해도, 모든 팟캐스트 중에서 상위 4%에 들어가게 돼요.
text_zh: 如果你每周发布一集，持续10周，你就能进入所有播客的前4%。
text_es: Si solo produces un episodio a la semana durante 10 semanas, estarás en el top 4% de todos los podcasts que se han creado.
key_sentence: Doing an episode weekly places you in the top 4% of all podcasts.

text: But figuring out how to create excitement internally and get buy-in from other teams because they're the ones that are going to build it. They're the ones that are going to help market.
speaker: Chris Hutchins
context: Lenny prompts Chris to share insights on successful innovation within larger companies. Chris explains that while understanding customer needs is vital, generating enthusiasm and securing support from various teams is equally important. This internal buy-in is crucial, as these teams will execute, market, and ultimately determine the success of a product.
text_ko: 내부에서 흥미를 유도하고 다른 팀들의 동의를 얻는 방법을 찾는 게 중요해요. 그 팀들이 실제로 만들고, 마케팅도 도와줄 사람들이니까요.
text_zh: 但关键在于如何在内部激发热情，并获得其他团队的支持，因为他们将是实施这一方案的人，他们也将帮助进行市场推广。
text_es: Pero hay que encontrar la manera de generar entusiasmo internamente y conseguir el apoyo de otros equipos, ya que son ellos quienes lo van a construir. Son ellos quienes ayudarán a comercializarlo.
key_sentence: Create excitement internally to get buy-in from other teams.

text: The harsh reality of this whole game is like there's probably going to be a number of months or years you have to do it for free before it takes off. So if you don't love it, that's going to be a painful few years.
speaker: Chris Hutchins
context: In discussing the challenges of starting a podcast, Chris emphasizes the potential long-term commitment and effort required before achieving success. He stresses the importance of passion for the topic, as those who do not genuinely enjoy the process may find it challenging over time. This insight serves as a reminder to choose subjects that ignite enthusiasm.
text_ko: 이 게임의 현실은 아마도 몇 개월 또는 몇 년 동안은 무료로 해야 할 수도 있다는 거예요. 그래서 만약 이 일을 사랑하지 않으면, 힘든 몇 년이 될 거예요.
text_zh: 这个行业的残酷现实是，你可能需要无偿付出几个月甚至几年，才能看到成果。因此，如果你不热爱这份工作，这将是几年的痛苦经历。
text_es: La dura realidad de este negocio es que probablemente habrá varios meses o incluso años en los que tendrás que trabajar sin remuneración antes de que despegue. Así que, si no lo amas, esos años pueden ser muy difíciles.
key_sentence: The harsh reality is you may face painful few years before success.

text: So I just think it's a simple way to build a podcasting website. The only other thing, we didn't talk at all about analytics at all, but I use Chartable for analytics.
speaker: Chris Hutchins
context: Lenny and Chris are discussing the podcasting tools and software they use. Chris shares his experience with using Podpage for creating a podcast website and mentions Chartable for analytics. He highlights the importance of having a user-friendly website and effective analytics to track podcast performance.
text_ko: 그래서 저는 팟캐스트 웹사이트를 만드는 게 정말 간단하다고 생각해요. 그리고 하나 더, 우리는 분석에 대해서는 전혀 얘기하지 않았는데, 저는 분석을 위해 Chartable을 사용해요.
text_zh: 我认为建立一个播客网站的方法很简单。我们没有讨论分析（analytics），但我使用Chartable进行数据分析。
text_es: Así que creo que es una forma sencilla de crear un sitio web de podcasting. Lo único que no mencionamos en absoluto son las analíticas, pero yo utilizo Chartable para eso.
key_sentence: It's a simple way to build a podcasting website using analytics.

text: One thing that I always say is, if you're going to dinner party, you now know someone's address. You probably know their name instead of bringing a bottle of wine or in addition, just check if they have unclaimed money.
speaker: Chris Hutchins
context: Chris shares a creative money hack about checking for unclaimed funds that a person might be owed. He suggests that knowing someone's name and address can lead to a fun conversation at social gatherings by revealing whether they have unclaimed money. This approach not only serves as a clever icebreaker but can also benefit the individual receiving the information.
text_ko: 제가 항상 하는 말이 있어요. 만약 저녁 파티에 간다면, 그 사람의 주소는 알게 되잖아요. 그 사람의 이름도 알겠죠. 그러니까 와인 한 병을 가져가는 대신에, 혹은 추가로, 그 사람이 받을 수 있는 돈이 있는지 확인해보는 것도 좋을 것 같아요.
text_zh: 我常说的一句话是，如果你要去参加晚宴，你现在知道了某人的地址。你可能知道他们的名字，不妨在带一瓶酒之前，先查一下他们是否有未领取的款项。
text_es: Una cosa que siempre digo es que, si vas a una cena, ahora conoces la dirección de alguien. Probablemente sepas su nombre, así que en lugar de llevar una botella de vino o además de eso, solo verifica si tienen dinero no reclamado.
key_sentence: Check for unclaimed money as an icebreaker at dinner parties.
